docs.lead_paragraph: Female athletes, coaches, administrators, educators and entrepreneurs gathered here this weekend to celebrate their accomplishments and to prepare for the challenges ahead. In assessing the state of women in sports, those attending the 14th annual conference of the Women's Sports Foundation agreed that there were more opportunities for women since Title IX of the 1972 Educational Amendments banned sex discrimination in federally funded school programs. Now, in a stance that reflects the influence of the foundation and its constituency, the group wants to focus less on getting in and more on moving up.

headline.main: Women's Sports Foundation Expands Mission Beyond Opening Doors

docs.abstract: Female athletes, coaches, administrators, educators and entrepreneurs gather in Uniondale, LI, at 14th annual conference of Women's Sports Foundation to celebrate their accomplishments and to prepare for challenges ahead (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It has been 11 years since Alex Martin was born, a 1-pound 2-ounce bundle of miniature bones and bright red skin, with fingers no bigger than matchsticks and legs so thin they might have fit inside his father's wedding band. His parents, Rick and Allison, waited four months to send birth announcements. ''The doctors kept telling us we had to plan for his funeral,'' Mrs. Martin explained. Today, Alex is a blond-haired, fair-skinned fifth grader with clear brown eyes, gold-rimmed glasses and a collection of what his mother calls labels: mild cerebral palsy, asthma, hyperactivity and Asperger's syndrome, a form of autism. At an age when most children have conquered fractions, Alex wrestles with addition. He learned to read about a year ago and is racing through the Hardy Boys series. But speaking is a challenge; words roll around like marbles in his mouth.

headline.main: As the Tiniest Babies Grow, So Can Their Problems

docs.abstract: Scientists are beginning to document that lives of babies born prematurely grow more complicated over time, with academic and behavioral problems often surfacing during school years; findings are at odds with conventional wisdom that premature babies who are not seriously physically disabled will catch up to other youngsters by age five; recent study of 150 teenagers born prematurely shows that nearly one-third have significant physical disorders and that even those with minor physical problems scored significantly lower on achievement tests than those in control group; findings intensify long-running debate about the ethics of using sophisticated technology to save children with uncertain futures; Rick and Alison Marty describe the array of physical and mental challenges facing their 11-year-old son, Alex, who at birth weighed one pound and two ounces; photos (M)
